By Ujjwal Narayan
NewsRise
NEW DELHI (Feb 23) -- India’s Supreme Court today urged Amazon and Future Group to approach the National Company Law Appellate Tribunal to quickly decide on the U.S. company’s appeal that challenged the antitrust watchdog’s order for suspension of the Future Coupons stake buy deal.

“We ask both the parties to approach NCLAT for expeditious disposal of the case,” a bench led by Chief Justice N.V. Ramana said.

The top court was hearing Amazon’s plea challenging the Delhi High Court's January order, staying further arbitration proceedings before the Singapore tribunal against Future Group till Feb. 1.

The top court asked Amazon to wait for the lower court to wrap up hearing in a dispute with Future Group over its proposed sell out to Reliance Industries in a $3.4 billion deal.

“If we hear you (Amazon), then the proceedings before the High Court will become useless,” Justice Ramana observed. The apex court adjourned the next hearing in the case to Mar. 9.

In 2019, Amazon invested $200 million in Future Coupons, the group’s gift voucher unit, for a 49% stake, which gave the U.S. company a 7.3% foothold in flagship Future Retail.

However, the two companies fell out after debt-laden Future Group agreed to sell its retail, wholesale, warehousing, and logistics businesses to billionaire Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries, in August 2020.

Amazon tried to block the deal by getting a freeze order from Singapore arbitration court. Future Group’s prospective sell out to Reliance threatens the U.S. company’s dominance in India. The deal with Reliance is crucial for Future Group, which is on the brink of liquidation.

In December, the Competition Commission of India had suspended Amazon’s deal with Future Coupons, saying the U.S. company concealed information while filing for regulatory approval. It accused Amazon of suppressing the actual scope of the deal and making “false and incorrect statements.” Earlier this month, NCLAT adjourned to Feb. 25 a hearing in the case filed by Amazon challenging the antitrust watchdog’s revocation of the U.S. online retailer’s stake purchase in Future.
